body: You can throw exceptions in `__toString()` since PHP 7.4. It looks like this method is used only in two places. I would rather deprecate this method, call `trigger_error()` directly in this two places only for PHP 7.3, and re-throw exception for higher versions of PHP.
I think that it is a bug that we convert exceptions to `E_USER_ERROR` for PHP 7.4 and above. It just makes handling such exceptions harder than it should be.

Well, we can use only trigger_error for `PHP 7.3`, we updated the phpdoc that the best way is throw exception, without needing to depreciate the method, so existing extensions or app will continue to work and if you use `PHP 8.4` it will also work.

I don't think it is worth to have `convertExceptionToError()` method that doesn't do what the name says in most of the cases (according to Packagist PHP 7.3 has less than 4% of installs). For Yii 2.2 that method would be completely pointless, so IMO the best course of action would be to deprecate it in 2.0 and remove in 2.2.

> I don't think it is worth to have `convertExceptionToError()` method that doesn't do what the name says in most of the cases (according to Packagist PHP 7.3 has less than 4% of installs). For Yii 2.2 that method would be completely pointless, so IMO the best course of action would be to deprecate it in 2.0 and remove in 2.2.

So should we remove support for PHP 7.3?

In 2.0.x (`master` branch):

1. Deprecate `convertExceptionToError()` and don't use it in the framework. 
2. In places where it was used, call `trigger_error()` directly for `PHP_VERSION_ID < 70400` and re-throw exception for other cases.

In 2.2.x:

1. Remove `convertExceptionToError()`. 
2. Remove try-catch and `trigger_error()` in these two places where we had this hack for exceptions in `__toString()` - they're no longer needed, since 2.2 requires PHP 8.1 which handles exceptions in `__toString()` just fine.
